verses.verse: Three days later there was a wedding in Cana of Galilee. The mother of Jesus was there.
Both Jesus and his disciples were also invited to the wedding.
When they ran out of wine Jesus' mother said to him, "They don't have any wine."
Jesus said to her, "Woman, what [is it] to me and you. My time hasn't come yet."
His mother told the servants, "Whatever he says to you, do."
Now there were six stone water jars for purifying in the Jewish manner, each containing two or three measures.
Jesus said to them, "Fill the water jars with water." So they completely filled them to the brim.
Then he said to them, "Now draw some out and carry to the man in charge of the dining room." So they took [it].

When the man in charge of the dining room had tasted the water that was made into wine but unaware of where it came from (but the servants who had drawn the water knew), the man in charge of the dining room addressed the bridegroom
and said to him, "Every one sets out the good wine at the beginning, and when all have drunk a lot then what is inferior. You have kept the good wine until now."
Jesus did this, the beginning of miracles, in Cana of Galilee. He clearly showed his glory, and his disciples believed in him.
After this he, his mother, his brothers, and his disciples went down to Capernaum and stayed there a few days.
The time for the Jew's Passover was near, so Jesus went to Jerusalem.
In the temple he found those who sold ox, sheep, doves, and money changers sitting.
After he had made a whip from small cords, he drove them all out from the temple, both sheep and ox. Then he poured out the money changerÂ» s money and overturned the tables.
Then he said to those who sold doves, "Take these things out of here, do not make my Father's house a marketplace."
His disciples remembered that it was written, "The zeal of your house has eaten me up."
Then the Jews answered and said to him, "What sign do you show to us why you do these things"?
Jesus answered and said to them, "Destroy this temple, and I will raise it again."
And so the Jews snarled, "It has taken forty-six years to build this temple, and you are going to raise it in three days?"
But he was speaking about the temple of his body.
Therefore when he had been raised from the dead, his disciples remembered that he had said this to them, and they believed the Scripture and the statement that Jesus had said.
Now when he was in Jerusalem at the Passover Festival, many believed in his name, when they saw the miracles, which he did,
but Jesus did not trust himself with them, because he knew all people.
He didn't need anyone to tell him about them, because he knew what was in man.
